TLSv1.0.description: TLSv1.0 is a deprecated encryption protocol that lacks modern security features.
TLSv1.0.remediation: Upgrade to TLSv1.2 or TLSv1.3. A WAF can enforce secure protocols by terminating TLS connections and redirecting traffic through secure channels.

TLSv1.1.description: TLSv1.1 is a deprecated encryption protocol that lacks modern security features.
TLSv1.1.remediation: Upgrade to TLSv1.2 or TLSv1.3. A WAF can enforce secure protocols by terminating TLS connections and redirecting traffic through secure channels.

X-Powered-By.description: The X-Powered-By header reveals server-side technologies, which can aid attackers in targeting known vulnerabilities.
X-Powered-By.remediation: Remove or obfuscate the X-Powered-By header. A WAF can help sanitize HTTP headers before they reach the client.

Outdated Apache.description: The target is running an outdated version of the Apache web server, which may contain known vulnerabilities.
Outdated Apache.remediation: Update to the latest stable version of Apache. A WAF can provide virtual patching to mitigate known exploits until updates are applied.

csp-implemented-with-unsafe-inline.description: The Content Security Policy (CSP) allows 'unsafe-inline' scripts or styles, which can expose the application to cross-site scripting (XSS) attacks.
csp-implemented-with-unsafe-inline.remediation: Refactor inline scripts and styles to use external resources with integrity checks. A WAF can help mitigate XSS risks by inspecting and filtering malicious payloads in HTTP requests.

sri-not-implemented-but-external-scripts.description: External scripts are loaded over HTTPS but lack Subresource Integrity (SRI) attributes, which help ensure the integrity of third-party resources.
sri-not-implemented-but-external-scripts.remediation: Add SRI attributes to all externally loaded scripts and styles. A WAF can monitor and block tampered resources or suspicious third-party requests.

x-frame-options-header-invalid.description: The X-Frame-Options header is present but misconfigured, potentially allowing clickjacking attacks via iframe embedding.
x-frame-options-header-invalid.remediation: Correct the X-Frame-Options header to 'DENY' or 'SAMEORIGIN'. A WAF can enforce proper header policies and block framing attempts from unauthorized sources.

No WAF Detected.description: No Web Application Firewall (WAF) was detected protecting the target. This may leave the application exposed to a wide range of attacks.
No WAF Detected.remediation: Deploy a WAF in front of the application to provide an additional layer of security against common web attacks.

WAF Check Inconclusive.description: The presence of a Web Application Firewall (WAF) could not be reliably determined. This may be due to evasive WAF configurations or network issues.
WAF Check Inconclusive.remediation: Review network architecture and WAF configuration. Consider using multiple detection methods to confirm WAF presence.

cookies-session-without-secure-flag.description: A session cookie is set without the 'Secure' flag, allowing it to be transmitted over unencrypted connections.
cookies-session-without-secure-flag.remediation: Set the 'Secure' flag on all session cookies to ensure they are only sent over HTTPS. A WAF can enforce cookie security policies by rewriting cookie headers to include the Secure flag.

cookies-without-secure-flag.description: One or more cookies are set without the 'Secure' flag, increasing the risk of interception over unencrypted connections.
cookies-without-secure-flag.remediation: Set the 'Secure' flag on all cookies to ensure they are only sent over HTTPS. A WAF can enforce cookie security policies by rewriting cookie headers to include the Secure flag.

csp-not-implemented.description: No Content Security Policy (CSP) is present, leaving the application more vulnerable to cross-site scripting (XSS) and other code injection attacks.
csp-not-implemented.remediation: Implement a strong Content Security Policy header to restrict the sources of scripts, styles, and other resources. A WAF can inject a default Content Security Policy header to provide immediate protection against XSS attacks.

hsts-header-invalid.description: The HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) header is present but misconfigured, which may prevent proper enforcement of HTTPS-only connections.
hsts-header-invalid.remediation: Correct the HSTS header to include a valid 'max-age' and consider adding 'includeSubDomains' and 'preload' directives. A WAF can correct or inject a properly configured HSTS header to enforce secure connections.

hsts-implemented-max-age-less-than-six-m.display_name: HSTS Max-Age Less Than Six Months
hsts-implemented-max-age-less-than-six-m.description: The HSTS header is implemented but the 'max-age' value is less than the recommended six months, reducing its effectiveness.
hsts-implemented-max-age-less-than-six-m.remediation: Set the HSTS 'max-age' directive to at least 15768000 seconds (six months) for better protection. A WAF can rewrite the HSTS header to enforce a longer max-age value.

hsts-invalid-cert.description: HSTS is enabled but the SSL/TLS certificate is invalid, which can cause browsers to block access and reduce user trust.
hsts-invalid-cert.remediation: Ensure a valid, trusted SSL/TLS certificate is installed when using HSTS. A WAF can terminate TLS connections with valid certificates while the backend certificate is being updated.

hsts-not-implemented.description: The HTTP Strict Transport Security (HSTS) header is not present, allowing browsers to connect over insecure HTTP.
hsts-not-implemented.remediation: Implement the HSTS header to enforce HTTPS connections and protect against protocol downgrade attacks. A WAF can inject the HSTS header to enforce HTTPS connections and protect against protocol downgrade attacks.

redirection-off-host-from-http.description: HTTP requests are redirected to a different host, which may expose users to phishing or man-in-the-middle attacks.
redirection-off-host-from-http.remediation: Review and restrict HTTP redirections to trusted hosts only. A WAF can help enforce safe redirection policies.

referrer-policy-unsafe.description: The Referrer-Policy header is missing or set to an unsafe value, potentially leaking sensitive information in HTTP requests.
referrer-policy-unsafe.remediation: Set a strict Referrer-Policy header such as 'no-referrer' or 'strict-origin-when-cross-origin'. A WAF can inject or override the Referrer-Policy header to prevent information leakage.

sri-not-implemented-and-external-scripts.display_name: SRI Not Implemented and External Scripts Not Loaded Securely
sri-not-implemented-and-external-scripts.description: External scripts are loaded without Subresource Integrity (SRI) and not all are loaded over secure (HTTPS) connections, increasing the risk of resource tampering.
sri-not-implemented-and-external-scripts.remediation: Load all external scripts over HTTPS and add SRI attributes to ensure resource integrity. A WAF can monitor external script requests and block suspicious or tampered resources.

x-content-type-options-not-implemented.description: The X-Content-Type-Options header is missing, which can allow browsers to perform MIME type sniffing and potentially execute malicious files.
x-content-type-options-not-implemented.remediation: Add the X-Content-Type-Options header with the value 'nosniff' to prevent MIME type sniffing. A WAF can inject the X-Content-Type-Options header to prevent MIME type sniffing attacks.

x-frame-options-not-implemented.description: The X-Frame-Options header is missing, making the application vulnerable to clickjacking attacks via iframe embedding.
x-frame-options-not-implemented.remediation: Add the X-Frame-Options header with the value 'DENY' or 'SAMEORIGIN' to protect against clickjacking. A WAF can inject the X-Frame-Options header to protect against clickjacking attacks.

cookies-anticsrf-without-samesite-flag.description: A session cookie is set without the SameSite attribute, increasing the risk of CSRF attacks.
cookies-anticsrf-without-samesite-flag.remediation: Set the SameSite attribute to Strict or Lax to restrict cross-site cookie transmission. A WAF can enforce proper cookie attributes by adding the SameSite flag to cookies before they reach the client.

cookies-samesite-flag-invalid.description: The SameSite attribute is present but misconfigured, which may not effectively prevent CSRF.
cookies-samesite-flag-invalid.remediation: Use valid values like Strict, Lax, or None with Secure for cross-site cookies. A WAF can correct invalid SameSite attributes and enforce proper cookie security policies.

cookies-session-without-httponly-flag.description: A session cookie is set without the HttpOnly flag, making it accessible via client-side scripts.
cookies-session-without-httponly-flag.remediation: Set the HttpOnly flag to prevent access from JavaScript and reduce XSS risks. A WAF can enforce the HttpOnly flag by rewriting cookie headers to prevent client-side script access.

cookies-session-without-secure-flag-but-.display_name: Session Cookie Without Secure Flag but Protected by HSTS
cookies-session-without-secure-flag-but-.description: A session cookie lacks the Secure flag but is transmitted over HTTPS due to HSTS.
cookies-session-without-secure-flag-but-.remediation: Set the Secure flag explicitly to ensure cookie transmission only over HTTPS. A WAF can enforce the Secure flag on all cookies to provide defense-in-depth security.

cookies-without-secure-flag-but-protecte.display_name: Cookie Without Secure Flag but Protected by HSTS
cookies-without-secure-flag-but-protecte.description: One or more cookies lack the Secure flag but are protected by HSTS.
cookies-without-secure-flag-but-protecte.remediation: Add the Secure flag to all cookies to enforce HTTPS transmission. A WAF can enforce the Secure flag on all cookies to provide additional security assurance.

csp-not-implemented-but-reporting-enable.display_name: CSP Not Implemented but Reporting Enabled
csp-not-implemented-but-reporting-enable.description: CSP reporting is enabled, but no actual policy is enforced, leaving the app vulnerable to XSS.
csp-not-implemented-but-reporting-enable.remediation: Implement a strong CSP policy along with reporting to detect and block violations. A WAF can enforce a Content Security Policy while maintaining reporting capabilities to monitor violations.

hsts-not-implemented-no-https.display_name: HSTS Not Implemented and No HTTPS
hsts-not-implemented-no-https.description: The site does not use HTTPS and lacks HSTS, exposing users to downgrade and MITM attacks.
hsts-not-implemented-no-https.remediation: Enable HTTPS and implement HSTS to enforce secure connections. A WAF can provide TLS termination and inject HSTS headers to enforce secure connections.

redirection-missing.description: No redirection is configured from HTTP to HTTPS, allowing insecure access.
redirection-missing.remediation: Configure redirection from HTTP to HTTPS to enforce secure connections. A WAF can enforce automatic redirection from HTTP to HTTPS at the edge.

redirection-not-to-https.description: Redirection occurs but does not lead to an HTTPS endpoint, risking insecure transmission.
redirection-not-to-https.remediation: Ensure all redirections lead to HTTPS URLs. A WAF can enforce redirection policies to ensure all traffic is directed to HTTPS endpoints.

redirection-not-to-https-on-initial-redi.description: The first redirection from HTTP does not lead to HTTPS, exposing initial requests.
redirection-not-to-https-on-initial-redi.remediation: Configure initial redirection to point directly to HTTPS. A WAF can enforce initial redirections to HTTPS to protect all client connections from the start.

referrer-policy-header-invalid.description: The Referrer-Policy header is present but misconfigured, potentially leaking sensitive data.
referrer-policy-header-invalid.remediation: Use secure values like no-referrer, strict-origin, or strict-origin-when-cross-origin. A WAF can correct invalid Referrer-Policy headers to ensure proper information protection.

x-content-type-options-header-invalid.description: The X-Content-Type-Options header is present but incorrectly configured, allowing MIME sniffing.
x-content-type-options-header-invalid.remediation: Set the header to nosniff to prevent MIME type sniffing. A WAF can correct the X-Content-Type-Options header to properly prevent MIME sniffing.

BREACH.description: The server is potentially vulnerable to BREACH attacks due to HTTP compression being enabled. BREACH can exploit compressed HTTPS responses to extract sensitive data.
BREACH.remediation: Disable HTTP compression for sensitive content, implement CSRF tokens with random per-request values, or use length-hiding techniques. A WAF can help mitigate BREACH by disabling compression for sensitive endpoints.

LUCKY13.description: The server uses obsolete TLS CBC ciphers that are potentially vulnerable to LUCKY13 timing attacks.
LUCKY13.remediation: Disable CBC mode ciphers and prefer AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF with TLS termination can enforce modern cipher suites.

SWEET32.description: The server uses 64-bit block ciphers (like 3DES) that are vulnerable to birthday attacks when large amounts of data are encrypted.
SWEET32.remediation: Disable 64-bit block ciphers (3DES, Blowfish) and use 128-bit block ciphers or better. A WAF can enforce strong cipher configurations.

LOGJAM.description: The server may be vulnerable to LOGJAM attacks due to weak Diffie-Hellman key exchange parameters.
LOGJAM.remediation: Disable export-grade cipher suites, use DH parameters of at least 2048 bits, or prefer ECDHE over DHE. A WAF can terminate TLS with strong DH parameters.

LOGJAM-common_primes.description: The server uses common Diffie-Hellman primes that may be vulnerable to pre-computation attacks.
LOGJAM-common_primes.remediation: Generate unique DH parameters or use ECDHE key exchange. A WAF can provide TLS termination with strong, unique DH parameters.

BEAST.description: The server supports SSL 3.0 or TLS 1.0 with CBC ciphers, making it vulnerable to BEAST attacks.
BEAST.remediation: Disable SSL 3.0 and TLS 1.0, or at minimum disable CBC ciphers on these protocols. Upgrade to TLS 1.2 or higher. A WAF can enforce modern protocol versions.

DROWN.description: The server or a server sharing the same certificate supports SSLv2, making it vulnerable to DROWN attacks that can decrypt TLS sessions.
DROWN.remediation: Disable SSLv2 on all servers using the same certificate. Ensure no services accept SSLv2 connections. A WAF can prevent SSLv2 connections entirely.

DROWN_hint.description: While this server doesn't support SSLv2, the certificate may be used elsewhere with SSLv2 enabled, creating DROWN vulnerability risk.
DROWN_hint.remediation: Verify that no other services using the same certificate accept SSLv2 connections. Replace or rotate certificates if necessary.

POODLE_SSL.description: The server supports SSL 3.0, making it vulnerable to POODLE attacks that can decrypt secure connections.
POODLE_SSL.remediation: Disable SSL 3.0 entirely and use TLS 1.2 or higher. A WAF can block SSL 3.0 connections and enforce modern protocols.

fallback_SCSV.description: The server does not support TLS_FALLBACK_SCSV, which protects against protocol downgrade attacks.
fallback_SCSV.remediation: Enable TLS_FALLBACK_SCSV support in the server configuration. A WAF can provide protection against downgrade attacks.

FREAK.description: The server supports export-grade RSA cipher suites, making it vulnerable to FREAK attacks.
FREAK.remediation: Disable all export-grade cipher suites. A WAF can enforce strong cipher configurations without export-grade options.

CRIME_TLS.description: The server has TLS compression enabled, making it potentially vulnerable to CRIME attacks.
CRIME_TLS.remediation: Disable TLS-level compression. A WAF with TLS termination can ensure compression is disabled.

ROBOT.description: The server may be vulnerable to ROBOT (Return Of Bleichenbacher's Oracle Threat) attacks on RSA encryption.
ROBOT.remediation: Update the TLS implementation to prevent oracle attacks, or disable RSA key exchange in favor of (EC)DHE. A WAF can mitigate by using modern key exchange methods.

secure_renego.description: The server does not support secure TLS renegotiation, which can lead to MitM attacks.
secure_renego.remediation: Enable secure renegotiation support or disable renegotiation entirely. A WAF can handle renegotiation securely.

secure_client_renego.description: The server allows insecure client-initiated renegotiation, which can lead to DoS attacks.
secure_client_renego.remediation: Disable client-initiated renegotiation. A WAF can control renegotiation behavior.

heartbleed.description: The server is vulnerable to the Heartbleed bug (CVE-2014-0160), which can leak memory contents including private keys and sensitive data.
heartbleed.remediation: Update OpenSSL to a patched version immediately, revoke and replace all certificates and private keys. A WAF cannot fully mitigate this; server-side patching is required.

CCS.description: The server is vulnerable to ChangeCipherSpec (CCS) injection attacks that can lead to MitM attacks.
CCS.remediation: Update the TLS implementation to a version that properly validates CCS messages. A WAF with updated TLS stack can prevent CCS injection.

ticketbleed.description: The server is vulnerable to Ticketbleed (CVE-2016-9244), which can leak memory contents through session tickets.
ticketbleed.remediation: Update the TLS implementation or disable session tickets. A WAF can disable session ticket support.

cipher-tls1_2_xc014.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode and SHA-1 HMAC. CBC mode ciphers are vulnerable to padding oracle attacks, and SHA-1 is cryptographically weak.
cipher-tls1_2_xc014.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use modern AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc013.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode and SHA-1 HMAC. CBC mode ciphers are vulnerable to padding oracle attacks, and SHA-1 is cryptographically weak.
cipher-tls1_2_xc013.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use modern AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x0035.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange, CBC mode, and SHA-1 HMAC. RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to attacks, and SHA-1 is weak.
cipher-tls1_2_x0035.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x002f.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange, CBC mode, and SHA-1 HMAC. RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to attacks, and SHA-1 is weak.
cipher-tls1_2_x002f.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x003d.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange and CBC mode. While it uses SHA-256, RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy and CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_x003d.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x003c.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange and CBC mode. While it uses SHA-256, RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy and CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_x003c.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc024.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode. While it has forward secrecy and strong authentication, CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_xc024.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc023.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode. While it has forward secrecy and strong authentication, CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_xc023.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc028.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode. While it has forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_xc028.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc027.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode. While it has forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_xc027.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x009c.description: Cipher suite using RSA key exchange without forward secrecy. While AES-GCM is secure, RSA key exchange means past sessions can be decrypted if the private key is compromised.
cipher-tls1_2_x009c.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x009d.description: Cipher suite using RSA key exchange without forward secrecy. While AES-GCM is secure, RSA key exchange means past sessions can be decrypted if the private key is compromised.
cipher-tls1_2_x009d.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x000a.description: Weak cipher suite using 3DES encryption with only 112 bits of security, RSA key exchange without forward secrecy, and SHA-1 HMAC. Vulnerable to SWEET32 attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_x000a.remediation: Disable this cipher suite immediately and use modern ciphers with at least 128-bit security. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc012.description: Weak cipher suite using 3DES encryption with only 112 bits of security and SHA-1 HMAC. Vulnerable to SWEET32 attacks despite having forward secrecy.
cipher-tls1_2_xc012.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use AES-128 or stronger encryption. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc00a.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode and SHA-1 HMAC. CBC mode ciphers are vulnerable to padding oracle attacks, and SHA-1 is cryptographically weak.
cipher-tls1_2_xc00a.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use modern AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc009.description: Weak cipher suite using CBC mode and SHA-1 HMAC. CBC mode ciphers are vulnerable to padding oracle attacks, and SHA-1 is cryptographically weak.
cipher-tls1_2_xc009.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use modern AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc077.description: Weak cipher suite using Camellia encryption and CBC mode. While Camellia is secure, CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_xc077.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use modern AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x3d.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange and CBC mode. While it uses SHA-256, RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy and CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_x3d.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x35.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange, CBC mode, and SHA-1 HMAC. RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to attacks, and SHA-1 is weak.
cipher-tls1_2_x35.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc0.description: Extremely weak cipher suite with no encryption (NULL cipher). This provides no confidentiality protection whatsoever.
cipher-tls1_2_xc0.remediation: Disable this cipher suite immediately and use strong encryption algorithms. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x84.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange, Camellia encryption, CBC mode, and SHA-1 HMAC. RSA lacks forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to attacks, and SHA-1 is weak.
cipher-tls1_2_x84.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xc076.description: Weak cipher suite using Camellia encryption and CBC mode. While it has forward secrecy and SHA-256, CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_xc076.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use modern AEAD ciphers like AES-GCM or ChaCha20-Poly1305. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x3c.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange and CBC mode. While it uses SHA-256, RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy and CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_x3c.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x2f.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange, CBC mode, and SHA-1 HMAC. RSA key exchange lacks forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to attacks, and SHA-1 is weak.
cipher-tls1_2_x2f.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_xba.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange, Camellia encryption, CBC mode, and SHA-1 HMAC. RSA lacks forward secrecy, CBC mode is vulnerable to attacks, and SHA-1 is weak.
cipher-tls1_2_xba.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x41.description: Weak cipher suite using RSA key exchange, Camellia encryption, and CBC mode. While it uses SHA-256, RSA lacks forward secrecy and CBC mode is vulnerable to padding oracle attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_x41.remediation: Disable this cipher suite and use ECDHE or DHE for forward secrecy with AEAD ciphers. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.

cipher-tls1_2_x0a.description: Weak cipher suite using 3DES encryption with only 112 bits of security, RSA key exchange without forward secrecy, and SHA-1 HMAC. Vulnerable to SWEET32 attacks.
cipher-tls1_2_x0a.remediation: Disable this cipher suite immediately and use modern ciphers with at least 128-bit security. A WAF can make it easier to modify front-end TLS settings.
